docs.title: zsh-claude Workflow System
docs.text:
A smart context manager and workflow automation system for Claude Code integration with optimized plugin management.

  • Smart Context Management

    Auto-detect project types and gather Claude context from CLAUDE.md files and project structure

    Getting Started

  • Optimized Plugin System

    Antidote integration with 20+ plugins and 20-40% faster shell startup through lazy loading

    Plugin Optimization

  • Project Intelligence

    Smart detection for R packages, Quarto, research projects with storage tier awareness

    Project Types

  • Template System

    Create project-specific CLAUDE.md files from customizable templates

    Templates

docs.title: ✨ Context Manager (Phase 1 - Complete)
docs.text:
• Auto-detect project types - Automatically identify R packages, Quarto projects, research repos, and dev tools
  • Gather Claude context - Intelligently collect CLAUDE.md files and project structure information
  • Template system - Generate project-specific CLAUDE.md files from templates
  • Smart project info - Display project details with type-specific intelligence
  • Storage awareness - Detect and display storage location (local, Google Drive, OneDrive, Dropbox)

docs.title: ⚡ Plugin Management (Bonus)
docs.text:
• Antidote integration - Modern, fast plugin manager built on antibody
  • Optimized configuration - 20-40% faster shell startup times
  • 20+ plugins - Git tools, FZF, autosuggestions, syntax highlighting, and more
  • Lazy loading - Heavy plugins load only when needed
  • Easy management - Simple text file configuration

docs.title: 🚀 Future Phases
docs.text:
• Multi-storage navigation (local + Google Drive + OneDrive)
  • Ecosystem manager for package suites
  • Session management and restoration

docs.text:

docs.title: Project Philosophy
docs.text:
This project follows a progressive enhancement approach:

  1. Core functionality first - Context management and project detection
  2. Enhance existing workflows - Work with your current setup
  3. Future expansion - Multi-storage navigation, ecosystem management

  • R package development workflows (rpkg, rdev, etc.)

  • Git workflows (gst, ga, gcmsg)
  • Modern CLI tools (bat, eza, fd, rg)
  • Existing CLAUDE.md files in your projects

docs.title: proj-type
docs.text:
Detect and display the current project type.

Usage: 

proj-type [directory]

Output: - Project name - Project type (R Package, Quarto, Research, etc.) - Storage location (local, google-drive, etc.) - Storage tier (active, stable, archive, etc.) - Claude instruction status - Git status

Examples: 

# Check current directory
proj-type

# Check specific directory
proj-type ~/R-packages/active/rmediation

docs.title: proj-info
docs.text:
Display comprehensive project information with context.

Usage: 

proj-info [directory]

Output: - Full project context - Claude instruction files - Git status and branch info - Type-specific information (R package stats, etc.) - Project structure tree

Examples: 

# Show info for current project
proj-info

# Show info for specific project
proj-info ~/quarto-projects/extensions/unm-revealjs

docs.title: claude-ctx
docs.text:
Gather and display all Claude context files in the current project.

Usage: 

claude-ctx [directory]

Output: - List of CLAUDE.md files - Claude settings files - Content of primary CLAUDE.md

Examples: 

# Show Claude context for current project
claude-ctx

# Show for specific project
claude-ctx ~/R-packages/active/medfit

docs.title: claude-init
docs.text:
Create a new CLAUDE.md file from template based on project type.

Usage: 

claude-init [directory]

Behavior: - Auto-detects project type - Selects appropriate template - Fills in project name and description - Creates CLAUDE.md in project root

Supported project types: - R Package → Uses CLAUDE-rpkg.md template - Quarto Project → Uses CLAUDE-quarto.md template - Research Project → Uses CLAUDE-research.md template

Examples: 

# Create CLAUDE.md in current directory
claude-init

# Create for specific project
claude-init ~/R-packages/active/probmed

docs.title: claude-show
docs.text:
Display the content of CLAUDE.md for the current project.

Usage: 

claude-show [directory]

Behavior: - Finds primary CLAUDE.md file - Uses bat for syntax highlighting (if available) - Falls back to cat if bat not installed

Priority: 1. CLAUDE.md in project root 2. .claude/CLAUDE.md 3. First CLAUDE*.md file found

Examples: 

# Show CLAUDE.md
claude-show

# Show for specific project
claude-show ~/R-packages/active/rmediation

docs.title: proj-claude
docs.text:
Open Claude Code with automatic project context.

Usage: 

proj-claude [directory]

Behavior: - Checks for CLAUDE.md (warns if missing) - Shows context summary - Opens Claude Code in chat mode

Examples: 

# Open Claude Code for current project
proj-claude

# Open for specific project
cd ~/R-packages/active/mediationverse
proj-claude

docs.title: Test Suite Overview
docs.text:
The test suite is organized into two complementary test scripts:

Test File How to Run Tests Structure tests/test-structure.zsh ./tests/test-structure.zsh Files exist, executables, syntax Runtime tests/test-runtime.zsh source tests/test-runtime.zsh Aliases work, PATH correct, commands run Complete tests/run-all-tests.zsh source tests/run-all-tests.zsh Both structure + runtime

docs.title: Structure Tests (test-structure.zsh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Verify files, permissions, and configuration syntax

Tests: - ✅ .zshrc exists and sources without errors - ✅ Claude CLI is installed - ✅ Aliases are DEFINED in .zshrc - ✅ PATH export is DEFINED in .zshrc - ✅ All 6 command files exist and are executable - ✅ All 3 library files exist and are readable - ✅ All 4 templates exist - ✅ Plugin configuration exists - ✅ Documentation files exist - ✅ Backup files exist

How it works: - Runs in subprocess - Checks file system and configuration files - Does NOT test if aliases actually work (subprocess limitation)

Expected result: ~100% pass

docs.title: Runtime Tests (test-runtime.zsh)
docs.text:
Purpose: Verify configuration is loaded and working in your shell

Tests: - ✅ Aliases exist AND have correct values - ✅ cc='claude' (not 'claude-code') - ✅ All workflow aliases point to correct commands - ✅ PATH includes workflow commands directory - ✅ Commands are accessible via PATH - ✅ Commands execute successfully

How it works: - Must be SOURCED (not executed) - Runs in your current shell - Tests actual runtime behavior

Expected result: ~100% pass

docs.title: Command Design Philosophy
docs.text:
All commands follow these principles:

  1. Sensible defaults - Work without arguments in most cases
  2. Current directory - Operate on current directory by default
  3. Optional path - Accept directory path as optional argument
  4. Colorful output - Use colors for better readability
  5. Helpful errors - Provide actionable error messages

docs.text:

cd ~/R-packages/active/rmediation
proj-type          # Works on current directory

docs.text:

proj-type ~/R-packages/active/medfit
claude-ctx ~/quarto-projects/book

docs.title: Combining Commands

cd ~/R-packages/active/newpkg
proj-type          # Verify detection
claude-init        # Create CLAUDE.md
claude-show        # Review it
proj-claude        # Start coding

docs.title: Context Management
docs.text: Learn how zsh-claude-workflow gathers and manages context for Claude Code integration.

docs.title: What is Context?
docs.text:
Context includes all information Claude Code needs to understand your project:

  • CLAUDE.md files - Project-specific instructions
  • Project structure - Directory organization
  • Git information - Branch, status, recent commits
  • Type-specific data - R package stats, Quarto config, etc.
  • Storage information - Location and tier

docs.title: CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Primary instruction file for Claude Code:

Location Priority: 1. ./CLAUDE.md (project root) 2. ./.claude/CLAUDE.md (hidden directory) 3. ../CLAUDE.md (parent directory)

Multiple Files: - System finds all CLAUDE.md files in hierarchy - All files are presented to Claude Code - More specific files take precedence

docs.title: Claude Settings
docs.text:
Claude Code configuration files:

Files: - ./.claude/settings.json - Project settings - ./.claude/settings.local.json - Local overrides

docs.title: Automatic Context
docs.text:
The claude-ctx command automatically gathers:

claude-ctx

Output: - List of all CLAUDE.md files found - Content of primary CLAUDE.md - Claude settings files - Project metadata

docs.title: Context Summary
docs.text:
The proj-info command provides full context:

proj-info

Includes: - Project type and name - Storage location and tier - Git status and branch - CLAUDE.md files - Type-specific information - Project structure

docs.title: R Package Context
docs.text:
Additional Information: - Package name and version - R/ directory file count - tests/ directory status - Dependencies from DESCRIPTION - NAMESPACE exports

Example: 

cd ~/R-packages/active/rmediation
proj-info

docs.title: Quarto Project Context
docs.text: Additional Information: - Project title and type - Number of .qmd files - _quarto.yml configuration - Output formats

docs.title: Research Project Context
docs.text: Additional Information: - LaTeX files count - Bibliography files - Literature directory status

docs.title: Creating CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Use claude-init to create from template:

cd ~/R-packages/active/newpkg
claude-init

This creates a project-specific CLAUDE.md based on detected project type.

docs.title: Viewing Context
docs.text:
Use claude-show to display CLAUDE.md:

claude-show

Uses bat for syntax highlighting if available, otherwise uses cat.

docs.title: Editing CLAUDE.md
docs.text:
Edit directly:

vim CLAUDE.md
# or
code CLAUDE.md

docs.title: Multiple CLAUDE.md Files
docs.text:
When multiple files exist:

~/R-packages/active/rmediation/
├── CLAUDE.md              # Project-specific (highest priority)
└── .claude/
    └── CLAUDE.md          # Alternative location

The system shows all files and their locations.

docs.title: Global vs Project Context
docs.text:
Global Context: - ~/.claude/CLAUDE.md - User-wide preferences - Applied to all Claude Code sessions

Project Context: - ./CLAUDE.md - Project-specific instructions - Overrides or extends global context

docs.title: Git Context
docs.text:

  • Current branch
  • Uncommitted changes
  • Recent commits (last 5)
  • Remote repository URL

docs.title: Storage Context
docs.text:
Location and tier information:

Helps Claude understand: - Project stability (active vs archive) - Collaboration needs (local vs cloud) - Backup status

docs.title: Project Structure
docs.text:
Automatically generated file tree:

proj-info  # Includes structure

Limited to relevant directories and files for Claude.

docs.title: What to Include in CLAUDE.md
docs.text: ✅ Project-specific conventions - Naming patterns unique to your project ✅ Common tasks - Frequent operations Claude should know ✅ Architecture decisions - Important design choices ✅ Dependencies - Key libraries and their purposes ✅ Testing approach - How tests are organized and run

docs.title: What to Avoid
docs.text: ❌ Generic programming advice - Claude knows general patterns ❌ Obvious information - Directory structure Claude can see ❌ Outdated instructions - Keep it current or remove it ❌ Too much detail - Focus on what's non-obvious

docs.text: zsh-claude-workflow automatically detects different types of projects and provides type-specific intelligence.

docs.text:

proj-type

docs.title: 📄 Quarto Project
docs.text:
Detection Criteria: - Has _quarto.yml file - Has .qmd files

cd ~/quarto-projects/book

docs.title: 🔬 Research Project
docs.text:

Displayed Information: - Project name (directory name) - Number of LaTeX files - Number of bibliography entries

cd ~/research/paper-2024
proj-type

docs.title: 🛠️ Development Tool
docs.text:
Detection Criteria: - Has executable scripts - Has Makefile or build configuration - Doesn't match other types

Displayed Information: - Project name - Main executables - Build system

docs.title: 📁 Git Project
docs.text:
Detection Criteria: - Has .git directory - Doesn't match more specific types

Displayed Information: - Repository name - Current branch - Git status

docs.title: ❓ Unknown
docs.text:
Detection Criteria: - Doesn't match any known pattern

Displayed Information: - Directory name - General file counts

docs.text:
The system detects where your project is stored:

Location Path Pattern local ~/code/, ~/projects/ google-drive ~/Library/CloudStorage/GoogleDrive-* onedrive ~/Library/CloudStorage/OneDrive-* dropbox ~/Dropbox/

docs.title: Storage Tiers
docs.text:
Projects are categorized by tier:

Tier Path Pattern Purpose active */active/* Currently developed stable */stable/* Stable releases archive */archive/* Archived projects scratch */scratch/* Experimental work

Name: rmediation
Location: local / active

docs.title: Adding a New Project Type
docs.text:
To add support for a new project type:

  1. Edit lib/project-detector.sh
  2. Add detection function:
is_python_project() {
    local dir="${1:-$PWD}"
    [[ -f "$dir/setup.py" ]] || [[ -f "$dir/pyproject.toml" ]]
}
  1. Update get_project_type():
get_project_type() {
    # ...
    elif is_python_project "$dir"; then
        echo "python"
    # ...
}
  1. Add icon and label:
get_project_icon() {
    case "$1" in
        python) echo "🐍" ;;
        # ...
    esac
}

See Architecture for more details.

docs.title: Detection Priority
docs.text:
When multiple patterns match, detection follows this priority:

  1. R Package (most specific)
  2. Quarto Extension
  3. Quarto Project
  4. Research Project
  5. Development Tool
  6. Git Project (least specific)

This ensures the most accurate type is selected.

docs.text:

Used for: R packages (projects with DESCRIPTION file)

Example: 

cd ~/R-packages/active/newpackage
claude-init  # Creates CLAUDE.md from R package template

docs.title: 📄 Quarto Template
docs.text:
File: templates/CLAUDE-quarto.md

Used for: Quarto projects and extensions

Includes: - Quarto project structure - Markdown and code chunk conventions - Build and preview commands - Publishing guidelines

Placeholders: - {{PROJECT_NAME}} - Project name from _quarto.yml - {{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION}} - Project description - {{DATE}} - Current date

docs.title: 🔬 Research Template
docs.text:
File: templates/CLAUDE-research.md

Used for: Research projects with LaTeX

Includes: - Research project organization - LaTeX conventions - Bibliography management - Writing guidelines - Statistical analysis patterns

Placeholders: - {{PROJECT_NAME}} - Directory name - {{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION}} - "Research project" - {{DATE}} - Current date

docs.title: Template Placeholders
docs.text:

Placeholder Description Source {{PACKAGE_NAME}} Project/package name DESCRIPTION, _quarto.yml, or directory name {{PROJECT_NAME}} Project name Same as above {{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION}} Project description DESCRIPTION or default text {{DATE}} Current date System date (YYYY-MM-DD)

Create a new template in the templates/ directory:

cd ~/code/zsh-claude-workflow/templates
vim CLAUDE-python.md

docs.title: 2. Use Placeholders
docs.text:
Include placeholders in your template:

# CLAUDE.md for {{PROJECT_NAME}}

## About This Project

{{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION}}

**Created:** {{DATE}}

## Project-Specific Guidelines

[Your custom content here]

docs.title: 3. Update claude-init
docs.text:
Edit commands/claude-init to use your template:

case "$project_type" in
    rpkg)
        template="$TEMPLATE_DIR/CLAUDE-rpkg.md"
        ;;
    python)
        template="$TEMPLATE_DIR/CLAUDE-python.md"
        ;;
    # ...
esac

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
The claude-init command:

  1. Detects project type
  2. Selects appropriate template
  3. Reads template file
  4. Replaces placeholders with actual values
  5. Writes CLAUDE.md to project directory

docs.title: Substitution Code
docs.text:
From commands/claude-init:

# Read template
content=$(<"$template")

# Substitute placeholders
content="${content//\{\{PACKAGE_NAME\}\}/$project_name}"
content="${content//\{\{PROJECT_NAME\}\}/$project_name}"
content="${content//\{\{PROJECT_DESCRIPTION\}\}/$description}"
content="${content//\{\{DATE\}\}/$(date +%Y-%m-%d)}"

# Write CLAUDE.md
echo "$content" > "$dir/CLAUDE.md"

docs.title: Plugin Optimization Guide
docs.text:
Date: 2025-12-07

This guide explains the optimized plugin configuration and recommendations.

docs.title: 1. Lazy Loading (kind:defer)
docs.text: Plugins that are not needed immediately on shell startup are lazy-loaded: - Loads only when first used - Reduces startup time - No functionality loss

docs.title: 2. Remove Redundant Plugins
docs.text:
• common-aliases - Removed to avoid conflicts with your extensive custom aliases
  • vscode - Removed (you primarily use Claude Code)

docs.title: 3. Add High-Value Plugins
docs.text: Plugins that significantly enhance your workflow

docs.title: 1. FZF Integration ⭐⭐⭐⭐⭐
docs.text:
Why: Supercharges fuzzy finding across your system

Installation: 

brew install fzf

What it adds: - Ctrl+R - Fuzzy search command history (MUCH better than default) - Ctrl+T - Fuzzy find files in current directory - Alt+C - Fuzzy find and cd into directories - Works with your existing fd and bat for previews

Example usage: 

# Press Ctrl+R and type "git push"
# See all matching commands with fuzzy search

# Press Ctrl+T in ~/R-packages
# Fuzzy search all files with preview

# Press Alt+C
# Fuzzy search directories and jump to them

Plugin line: 

ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh path:plugins/fzf

docs.title: 2. You Should Use ⭐⭐⭐⭐
docs.text:
Why: Reminds you to use aliases you've already defined

What it does: 

$ git status
You should use: gst

$ git add .
You should use: ga .

$ proj-type
# (no reminder - you used the alias!)

Plugin line: 

MichaelAquilina/zsh-you-should-use

docs.title: 3. Fast Syntax Highlighting ⭐⭐⭐⭐ (Optional Alternative)
docs.text:
Why: Faster than zsh-syntax-highlighting with more features

Trade-off: More features but slightly more complex - Highlights commands in real-time - Shows if command exists before you run it - Highlights paths, options, strings differently

Plugin line (replaces zsh-syntax-highlighting): 

zdharma-continuum/fast-syntax-highlighting

docs.title: 4. Zsh Abbreviations ⭐⭐⭐ (Optional)
docs.text:
Why: Fish-like text expansion

What it does: 

# Define abbreviations
abbr gp="git push"
abbr rpd="cd ~/R-packages/active"

# Type 'gp' and press Space → expands to 'git push'
# You see full command before running

Plugin line: 

olets/zsh-abbr

Benefit: Unlike aliases, you see what actually runs (great for learning/safety)

docs.title: 5. Tmux Integration ⭐⭐⭐ (Optional)
docs.text:
Why: If you use tmux, better integration

What it adds: - Auto-start tmux on terminal launch - Aliases for tmux commands - Session management helpers

Plugin line: 

ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh path:plugins/tmux kind:defer

docs.title: 4. Separated Test Concerns
docs.text:

Runtime Tests (test-runtime.zsh): - Tests aliases actually work - Tests alias values are correct - Tests PATH is loaded - Tests commands execute - Must be sourced (runs in current shell)

Complete Tests (run-all-tests.zsh): - Runs both in sequence - Provides overall pass/fail - Clear phase separation
